Augustine, or were immediately ready to set up churches of their
own, as with the Jacksonville church which is known today as the
Bethel Baptist Institutional Church. Other early Negro religious
groups were the Methodist Episcopal Church in St. Augustine, founded
in 1864 and the African Methodist Church in Jacksonville, called
Mount Zion.

After emancipation, the rural Negro took full advantage of his
privilege to worship God. Lengthy camp meetings, held under the
shade of trees, were popular in all parts of Florida. People from
miles around gathered at the meeting place early in the day and
all-day services were held, the worshippers stopping only long
enough to have dinner. Baskets of food, which every family took
pride in filling to overflowing and fetching to the camp meeting,
were spread upon white cloths upon the ground. As economic cir
cumstances improved, the congregations were able to build churches,
and the old camp meetings gradually passed from the Florida scene.

Eduction. Jonathon Gibbs was as distinguished in the edu
ational field as in the political field. After serving four years
as secretary of state under Governor Reed, he became Florida's
first state superintendent of education in 1872. The state achieved
its first practical system of supervised public education under his
direction. He was instrumental in securing legislation by which a
state board of education was created and funds were appropriated to
maintain schools. The law also required the several counties to
supplement state expenditures.

The state schools were proceded by a system of free schools
established by the Freedmen's Bureau in several cities. A notable
example of the bureau's work was the Jacksonville Negro school,
which was constructed with the financial aid of local white citizens.
This institution grew and expanded, and evolved into the present-day
Staton High School30.352171 -81.672350. Cookman Institute29.212173 -81.032388, also in Jacksonville, was
founded in 1872. This was another of the bureau's ventures, and
out of it has developed Bethuns-Cookman College29.212173 -81.032388, located at Daytona
Beach. Third among the Negro school of higher learning established
after emancipation was Edward Waters College30.343684 -81.683699, a Methodist institu
tion founded in 1873. Like the others, it is still in existence,
though it has moved from Live Oak, its first location, to Jacksonville,
where it has a student body of several hundred.

The ex-slaves, both children and adults, were avid for the
educational opportunities which had previously been denied them.
Makeshift primary schools came into existence in all parts of Florida.
Later, they were gradually absorbed into the state school system.
It was a disturbing question whether of not white and black chil
dren should attend the same schools. This was finally solved by
the state constitution of 1885, which provided "White and colored
children shall not be taught in the same school but impartial
provision shall be made for both." Thereafter, segregation was
adhered to, but the educational facilities provided for colored
children were never equal to those provided for the white children.

div.head: The Years Between
div.p:
In the more than six decades following the collapse of Recon
struction, 1876-1940, the Negro-American people of Florida advanced
in may ways. Their state-wide political power had gradually van
ished, but a number of Negro Republicans gained prominence by answer
ing for the Negro vote. Others found careers in the arts, the business
world, and the religious field. Some entered the profession of worked
in the skilled and semi-skilled crafts and trades, and many became
owners of homes, farms, and small businesses. By giving him an impor
tant place in the state's economic life, these individual achievements
partly compensated for the Negro's losses in the political and social
spheres. Most of the Negro population, however, continued their work
in occupations which required unskilled labor.

Notable among Negro citizens who distinguished themselves after
the close of Reconstruction are the following:

Joseph Edward Lee. He was born in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, in
1848, attended public school there, and graduated from Howard Univer
sity Law School in 1872. Coming to Jacksonville, he was admitted to
the Florida bar in 1873. Lee served as judge of the municipal court
of Jacksonville from 1880 to 1882 and was a member of the Florida
legislature in 1882 and 1884. Appointed collector of customs for
Florida by President Harrison in 1884, he held this position until
1898. President William McKinley appointed him collector of internal
revenue for Florida in 1898; he served in that capacity under succeeding
administrations until the advent of President Woodrow Wilson in 1914.
He then resumed his private practice of law. At one time he was
elected clerk of the circuit court at Jacksonville but never served
because the county commissioners failed to approve anu bond he offered.

Lee was known as a brilliant orator and an astute politician.
He was a delegate to every National Republican Convention from 1880
until his death which occurred in Jacksonville, April 1920.

Sylvamus H. Hart. Born on a plantation, Darlington County, South
Carolina, in 1860, of slave parents, Hart came to Jacksonville from
Charleston in 1865 with his mother and step-father. The latter taught
him plastering and bricklaying, and he later became a contractor.
After two years as town clerk of LaVilla30.334787 -81.667064 and one year as tax assessor
of the same place, he established, in 1902, Hart's Bank, the first
bank to be operated by Negroes in Jacksonville. It functioned until
1913 when he closed it voluntarily and paid off his depositors in full.

Judson Douglass Wetmore. Born in Jacksonville September 24, 1870,
he was the son of George W. and Fannie Wetmore.

His early education was received at Cookman Institute29.212210 -81.032227, Jackson
ville; he graduated from the law school of the University of Michigan42.278075 -83.738364;
and he practiced law in Jacksonville and served with distinction as
a city councilman. Wetmore was noted for his fight against social
segregation, familiarly known as the "Jim Crow" law. He later moved
to New York City where he built up a lucrative practice.

Mathew McFarlin Lewey. Born in Baltimore, Maryland, 1845, Lewey
was educated in Baltimore and New York City private schools. He vol
unteered for service in the Federal Army in fall of 1863, and saw
service at the siege of Fort Wagner, the battle of James Island, and
the slaughter at Honey Hill, South Carolina. He was wounded three
times in the latter engagement while bearing the colors of his regi
ment.

After the war he completed a law course and came to Florida in
1873. For several years Lewey taught school and held a number of
minor political posts. Elected to the state legislature in 1882, he
served for two years, and was a member of the legislative committee
which recommended establishment of the Florida Agricultural and
Mechanical College30.425796 -84.282857 at Tallahassee.

In 1887, at Gainsvile, he founded the Florida Sentinel, a
weekly journal. Later it was published at Pensacola, and from 1913
to 1934 the editorial offices were located in Jacksonville. This
pioneer Negro publisher died August 18, 1935.

Captain James W. Floyd. A Negro mariner, Floyd was born in Duval
county, May 4, 1861. Learning navigation from his father, a tugboat
operator, he later became master of the famous tug Dauntless which
was engaged in smuggling contraband cargoes from the United States
into Cuba during the Spanish-American War. Floyd's skillful naviga
tion and courage enabled him to pass through heavy patrols on several
occasions.

After the conclusion of the war he was signally honored by the
Cuban Government. He was made an honorary member of the National
Association of Cuban Revolutionary Veterans, and awarded the Order of
Naval Merit, third class by a recent Cuban President.

Timothy Thomas Fortune. A native of Matianna, born of slave
parents, October 3, 1856, he attended Stanton public school in Jack
sonville. Fortune gained journalistic experience in the composing
room of the Courier, a daily Jacksonville newspaper. In 1879 he moved
to New York, where he edited first the Rumor, a Negro publication
of the time, and acquired considerable political influence through
his militant advocacy of Negro rights. Fortune wrote two books which
were widely read, Black and White and The Negro in Politics. His
writing career extended from 1880 until the 1930's.

John R. Scott. A native of South Carolina, Scott was born free,
eight years before the emancipation of the slaves. He moved to Jack
sonville in his youth and attended school there. Entered the Methodist
Episcopal ministry, and served for several successful years. Later,
Scott entered politics and become deputy collector of internal revenue
for Florida. At one time he was chairman of the State Republican
Convention.

(Add more biographies, and other information to this post-
Reconstruction period.)

div.head: Contemporary Life
div.p:
Business and the Professions. Florida's half-million Negroes
present many evidences in 1940 of the progress made by their race
in 250 years, on the peninsula. They have businesses ranging from
the small bootblack stands and restaurants found in every city to
two large insurance companies, one having assets of more than a
million dollars. Each city has from one to several undertaking es
tablishments, real estate offices, doctors, lawyers, and other pro
fessional men, in addition to a variety of small enterprises.

Some cities, like Miami, Tampa, and Jacksonville, have entire
city blocks where Negro stores and offices are the only ones to be
found. There are several sizable hotels operated by and for Negroes,
as well as hospitals and theaters. The Florida Negro has five weekly
newspapers: the Miami Times, the St. Petersburg Public Informer. and the St. Augus
tine Post. Among Negro magazines, the Quarterly of the Florida Agri
lish from a few columns to two pages of Negro news in what is known
as "star" editions of the papers. Thousands of Cuban-Negroes living
in Ybor City read the Spanish-language newspapers published there.

In the recreational field, there are several Negro beaches and
pleasure resorts, although the race is excluded from nearly all of
the famed resort areas of south Florida, even to the extent of an un
written law against the use of separate beaches. Bolita, an almost
universally-played, illegal game of chance which drains millions of
dollars annually from the slim pocketbooks of the Negro laboring pop
ulation, is partly controlled and operated by negro gamblers and their
henchmen.

Education. During the 1937-38 school term, 102,438 Negro children
and youths attended 1,029 public school in the state. At the same
time, there were 281,497 white students in 1,517 schools. It would
appear that, by comparison, the white schools were overcrowded, but
the white schools contained 12,429 rooms and the Negro schools,
1,672 rooms. The reverse condition was true; Negro schools were bad
ly overcrowded. A need for modernizing Negro school properties and
increasing their facilities was indicated by the fact that 945 were
frame structures and but 84 were brick or concrete. A large per
centage were rickety, often unsafe, buildings lacking sanitary con
venienced and a water supply. White students had 767 frame schools
and 750 of brick or concrete, the greater number of which were of
modern construction. The disparity is best explained by the lack of
county support of Negro schools. Nearly all white school have been
constructed by the county governments, but less than two-thirds of
the Negro buildings are county-owned. As an example, Duval County,
with a Negro population of 60,636 in 1935, largest in the state, had
only one Negro high school. Negro public properties in Florida
were valued at $5,148,000 in 1938; white properties at $73,167,000
for the same year.

Although the state constitution provides that "impartial provision"
shall be made for the school children of both races, there is a wide
difference in the amounts of money expended for white and Negro edu
cation. For the 1936-37 term, $17,357,000 were spent for the support
and maintenance of white schools and $2,333,000 for the Negro.

In 1937-38, the instructional personnel of Negro schools con
sisted of 17 supervisors, 47 principals, and 3,063 teachers. The
supervisors, partly supported by the Jeanes Fund, a private philan
throphy for Negro education, served as liaison agents between county
superintendents of public instruction and Negro schools.

A 1939 survey of the economic status of Negro teachers, issued by
the University of Florida29.644295 -82.354447, states the following:

"The average salary received by these teachers in 1934-35 was $457.
The lowest salary received was $120 and the highest $1,575. The
Florida School Bulletin of March 1, 1939, gives the average annual
salary of $573. This seems to represent a fairly substantial gain over
1934-35, but it is true that there has been an increase in the cost of
living that would affect this gain to a great extent. It is our opin
ion that the increase in salary has been off-set by the increase in
cost of living and has not increased the net income of Florida Negro
teachers since 1934-35.

"This situation offers a distinct challenge to the people of
Florida to place these public employees on such a salary that they
can have a decent standard of living and can prepare themselves for
and assume a place of leadership in the Negro race. Without it, we
will not be able to solve the difficult problems that face us in
Florida and the South."

White teachers of the state receive salaries far below the
national average, but their individual earnings are more than double
those of Negro teachers. This discriminatory wage scale is common
throught the South. In a test case, June 1940, the United States
Circuit Court of Appeals at Asheville, North Carolina, gave an opinion
that differentials in salary scales "because of race or color" are
unlawful. It was estimated that the court's decision would add
$1,320,000 annually to the salaries of Negro teachers in that state
alone. The test case was brought about by a union of North Carolina
Negro teachers which had a membership of 5,000. Application of this
equalization order to the Florida school system would raise teaching
from the least to one of the most remunerative Negro professions.

The 1935 state census listed 43,108 Negroes of high school age
in Florida, of whom 9,556 were enrolled in high schools during the
1937-38 term. Less than five per cent of the Negro youth complete
their high school courses, largely due to the necessity for earning
a living at an early age and partly because of the inadequate school
facilities. Thirty counties do not have Negro high schools. Only
five of the high school are accredited institutions, though two private
Negro colleges have high school departments on the accredited list.

Florida spends less on grammar and high schools, white and colored,
than the average state. Yet, in proportion to its income, which is
below the National level, Florida exceeds the average. It is apparent
that attempts to improve the school system are held in check by the
low average income of Florida citizens. Public schools are supported
by taxation, and, when incomes are low, taxes must be correspondingly
low.

There are seven private colleges and one state college for Negroes.
The latter, most important and largest of all, is the Florida Agri
cultural and Mechanical College for Negroes, located on a hilltop cam
pus at Tallahassee. It has a faculty of more than forty and an annual
enrollment that exceeds one thousand students. Originally a vocational
school, it now has full liberal arts courses and graduate work is of
fered in some fields.

The Negro Baptist Church endows two colleges: the Normal and
Industrial College at St. Augustine, with an estimated annual enroll
ment of about three hundred, and the Florida Memorial College at Live
Oak with about two hundred and fifty students. The Methodist Episco
pal Church has a junior college at Jacksonville. Also at
Jacksonville is the school operated by the African Methodist Church,

The Arts. A small but highly talented group of Florida Negroes
has earned fame in art, literature, and music. The state has produced
several Negro composers and orchestra leaders, at least one of whom
has become internationally famous. James Rosamond Johnson, born in
Jacksonville in 1881, has written the musical scores for a number of
Broadway shows, as well as a light operetta and many popular songs.
Among the nest known of his compositions in Under the Bamboo Tree, a
great success early in the century. His Lift Ev'ry Voice and Sing is
sung at every Negro patriotic gathering. A collection of his music,
Rolling Along in Song, was published in 1937.

Choirs of unusual merit are found in a number of Negro churches
in the larger cities, and several school groups have won notice out
side the state. There are annual song festivals at two of the col
leges.

In literature, Florida has contributed two outstanding Negro-
Americans. Foremost is James Weldon Johnson, brother of Rosamond,
whose Autobiography of an Ex-Colored Man went into several editions.

an influential position in national Negro affairs. Gifted with many
talents, he was by turn a teacher, lawyer, poet, writer of musical

An itinerant Baptist preacher's daughter, Zora Neale Hurston, is
Florida's second distinguished Negro writer. Born at Mandarin, she
has a home in Eatonville, and has resided in Harlem where she first
gained prominence as a member of the Negro literati. A fine stylist,
her writing reflect an insight into Negro emotional life. She has
produced five books since 1934--Jonah's Gourd Vine, Mules and Men,
Their Eyes Were Watching God, Tell My Horse, and Man on a Mountain,
in the order named. The first two display a wide knowledge of
anthropology and folklore, the third is a dramatic novel of the
Everglades, the fourth deals with ceremonial rites in Haiti and
Jamaica, and the last interprets the life of Moses.

Less famous for his writings than for his leadership, A. Philip
Randolph was born in Crescent City and educated in Jacksonville
schools. He has edited several Negro periodicals, and in 1917 he
was jailed with Eugene Debs for obstructing the war-time draft acts.
A commanding orator, Randolph held in 1940 two major posts in the
Negro-American world--the presidencies of the National Negro Congress
and the International Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters.

Another preacher's daughter, Augusta Savage, born in Green Cove
Springs, is regarded as the world's greatest Negro sculptor. She
achieved success in spite of years of poverty, and indifference of

the white and Negro public. Among her best-known works are Henry M.
Flagler, The Urchin, and symbolic representation of Lift Ev'ry Voice
and Sing, the Negro national anthem. The latter, executed in heroic
proportions, was commissioned by the New York World's Fair. It is
a huge harp, cradled in the hand of God, and its chords are famous
Negro singers. Savage gave the first Florida exhibition of her work
at Jacksonville in 1940.
